parts: Give this number of a capella voices used in an English motet which was written to rival Striggio's composition, titled Spem in Alium.

As it uses multiple voices with independent melodies, Thomas Tallis' Spem in Alium has this musical texture, whose name comes from the Greek for "many sounds". It was apocryphally "saved" by Palestrina's Pope Marcellus Mass.
To play all 40 voices of Spem in Alium on a single cello, Peter Gregson used this technique to record each voice separately and piece them together on a single tape recording.

answers: endings [or end of the novel, or finales]
the color of the text [or the color of the font; or the color of the words; prompt on formatting or typography; prompt on color by asking "color of what?"]
parts: Infinite Jest includes 388 of these things after the main text of the novel elaborating on plot details, much like how one might use these things in a research paper.

John Fowles' novel The French Lieutenant's Woman unusually includes two of these components. Charles Dickens changed this component of Great Expectations to have Pip meet Estella at Satis House instead of hearing of her marriage.
Many editions of Mark Z. Danielewski's House of Leaves change this property for parts of the novel that refer to the title building, to Johnny's mother, or to the Minotaur.

answers: blindness [accept equivalents describing loss of vision]
parts: Name this disease, the most common bacterial sexually transmitted infection.
Chlamydia is susceptible to penicillins despite lacking this substance, an observation called the "chlamydia anomaly". This polymer consists of repeating NAG and NAM units.

While Chlamydia trachomatis serotypes D through K cause an STI, serotypes A through C can lead to trachoma, which causes this condition. This condition is also caused by onchocerciasis (“on-koh-sir-KYE-uh-sis”).

answers: Syriac [accept West Syriac Rite or East Syriac Rite]
Thomas the Apostle [or Thoma Sheliha; accept Didymus; accept Doubting Thomas]
parts: Name this country, one of whose churches was reformed by Abraham Malpan. Christians in this country who opposed the Latinization of its traditions publicly swore the Coonan Cross Oath.
Kerala's Malankara Church performs its liturgy in this language, which was introduced to it by Gregorios Abdal Jaleel. The Chaldean Church's liturgy also uses this descendant of Aramaic.
Kerala Christians trace their origin to this apostle, who arrived on the Malabar Coast in 52 CE. This apostle is given the epithet "Doubting" for doubting Jesus's resurrection.

answers: Palatine Hill [accept Scholae Palatinae; prompt on palace by saying "we're looking for a geographic feature"]
comes ("koh-MAYS") [or comites; prompt on count by saying "we're looking for the Latin root of that word"]
parts: One major change in offices was Constantine's disbanding of this unit of guards due to their nasty habit of murdering emperors and installing new ones.

A group of elite scholae ("SKOH-lye") who served as imperial guards were named for this geographic feature in Rome where emperors lived. Before the imperial era, this place mainly housed the homes of the wealthy.
Late emperors filled many offices with trusted individuals denoted by this Latin word for "companion," including provincial administrators. A medieval title of minor nobility comes from this word.

answers: I. M. Pei [or Ieoh Ming Pei]
parts: Name this city which contains buildings like Tornado Tower and the 300-meter-tall Aspire Tower. The planned Lusail Iconic Stadium will be built north of this city.
Doha is home to the Museum of Islamic Art, which was designed at age 91 by this Chinese-American architect of the Louvre Pyramid.
In 2017, this Dutch architect completed the new Qatar National Library in Education City, Doha. This author of S, M, L, XL also designed the CCTV headquarters building.

answers: Salem witch trials [or Salem trials; prompt on witch trials or witch hunts by asking "where?"]
parts: Name this 17th century English author who is the attributed writer of the epigraphs of Edgar Allen Poe's stories "A Descent into the Maelström" and "Ligeia".
Glanvill's Saducismus was the model for Cotton Mather's book defending his role in these historical events, which are dramatized in Arthur Miller's play The Crucible.
This Matthew Arnold poem, based on a story from Glanvill's The Vanity of Dogmatizing, describes an Oxford student who leaves school to join a band of countryside wanderers.

answers: Lemon v. Kurtzman [accept either underlined portion; accept Lemon test]
Abington v. Schempp [or Abington School District v. Schempp; accept either underlined portion]
parts: Name this Burger court decision which ruled that a Pennsylvania law allowing for public reimbursement of Catholic school teachers in public schools was unconstitutional.
The Establishment Clause, stating "Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion," is from this amendment to the U.S. Constitution.
This other case regarding the Establishment Clause from Pennsylvania declared Bible reading in state-sponsored classrooms to be unconstitutional. It was decided by the Warren Court in 1963.
Name this historian whose biography of Alexander Hamilton was the inspiration for the musical of the same name.
Annette Gordon-Reed, who has criticized Hamilton as whitewashing history, is best known for writing a history of this woman. This slave likely had six children with her owner, Thomas Jefferson.
This author satirized Hamilton in the aforementioned The Haunting of Lin-Manuel Miranda. This author's The Complete Muhammad Ali analyzes the boxer's forays into politics.
Name these devices which produce coherent light via stimulated emission.
This widely used laser, which emits a wavelength of 633 nanometers, was the first gas laser to be developed. Its gain medium contains two noble gases.
This binary III-V ("three-five") semiconductor, which has a large band gap of 3.4 electron-volts, is widely used in blue laser diodes and blue LEDs, such as the ones found in Blu-ray discs.
Name this artist who often showed his subjects jumping. Elizabeth Arden used this artist's photo of Connie Ford against the American flag to advertise "Victory Red" lipstick.

A swirl of water flies at three cats in a Halsman photo that shows this artist floating in the air. This artist's painting of Leda Atomica was one of many he created during his "nuclear mysticism" period.
Halsman's photo of this pensive person appeared on the 1947 cover of Time magazine. Arthur Sasse took a photo of this scientist that shows him sticking his tongue out.

answers: thaler ("tah-lehr") [or Joachimsthaler; accept tolar ("tow-lahr"); accept Reichsthaler, Conventionsthaler, or Kronenthaler; prompt on dollars ("daw-lehrs")]
Maria Theresa [or Maria Theresa Walburga Amalia Christina; or Maria Theresia; prompt on partial answer]
parts: Name these silver coins, which became a standard unit of currency throughout the Holy Roman Empire and the rest of Europe. A Prussian version of this coin prefixed its name with "reichs".
At the time of the thaler's production, Bohemia was ruled by this dynasty. This dynasty's king Louis II, son of Vladislav II, was decisively defeated at the Battle of Mohacs ("moh-hach").
The most-widely circulated version of the thaler featured this queen's face on it. Her succession to the Habsburg throne was the subject of the War of Austrian Succession.
Name this type of SIMD operation on data frames that executes on entire arrays.
Methods like loc (“loke”) and iloc (“eye-loke”) are used to look up entries in dataframes in this package that shares its name with an animal.

Pandas is a library in this dynamically typed programming language often used for data analysis. This language created by Guido van Rossum uses whitespace to denote code blocks and uses the English word “and” for the boolean operator.

answers: Time Regained [or Le Temps retrouvé, or Finding Time Again; DO NOT REVEAL THESE ANSWERS OTHERWISE, but prompt on any of In Search of Lost Time, A Remembrance of Things Past, or À la recherche du temps perdu]
In Search of Lost Time [or Remembrance of Things Past; or À la recherche du temps perdu]
parts: Name this novel whose narrator wanders Paris during a blackout, reflecting on the carnage of World War I and a visit from his friend Saint-Loup ("sont-loop"), who dies in combat a few days later.
Time Regained is the last novel in this series by Marcel Proust ("proost"); its final flashback is similar to the madeleine scene from this series's first novel, Swann's Way.
The narrator of Time Regained has a flashback of this former love interest playing the piano. This recurring Proust character has many lesbian affairs and dies when she falls off a horse.
I-80 begins at the western entrance of a bridge that crosses this body of water and heads towards Oakland. Alcatraz is also located in this body of water.
I-80 passes by this fort, which is the first base that Oregon Trail travelers stopped at. This fort on the Platte River became obsolete with the opening of the Union Pacific Railroad.
Further east, I-80 is home to the world's largest truck stop in this state's city of Walcott. J.K. Daniels began the practice of sculpting cows out of butter during an iconic fair in this state.

answers: investment theory of party competition [or investor theory]
parts: What political science theorem suggests that parties compete by attempting to appeal to the namesake person in order to reach more than 50% of the electorate?

One alternative to the median voter theorem is this theory developed in Thomas Ferguson's book Golden Rule, which suggests that party competition is driven by people who have the greatest financial interests in politics.
Many models of party competition use techniques from this mathematical field, which studies situations like the stag hunt and prisoner's dilemma.

The Trowulan Museum houses many artifacts made of this material from the Majapahit empire, including the oldest known piggy bank. It was used to make an "army" for Qin Shi Huangdi's ("cheen shur hwang-di'z") tomb.

The Balaputradeva ("bah-lah-POO-truh-DEV-uh") Museum in Palembang ("PAH-lem-bong") has many artifacts from this Sumatra-based empire, which ruled a Buddhist thalassocracy from the 8th to 12th centuries.

Indonesia's National Museum houses a magnificent Prajnaparamita statue commissioned by this empire's greatest ruler, Kertanegara, who also incited the Mongol invasion of Java. It was displaced by the Majapahit empire.

answers: Iram of the Pillars [or Iram of the Tentpoles; or Iram dhat al-'imad; accept Ubar or Wabar]
camel [or dromedary; accept naqa (plural nuq or niyaq) or jamal (plural jimal); accept She-Camel of God; accept Battle of the Camel]
parts: Name this capital of the 'Ad, a legendary lost city in Arabia's Empty Quarter with lofty pillars.

Abdullah bin Qalabah finds Iram while looking for one of these animals. The Thamud are wiped out for killing one of these animals sent by God. Ali defeated Aisha at a battle named for one of these animals.
To warn of God's punishment of unbelievers, the Surah al-Fajr notes the fates of Iram, the Thamud, and this ruler who rejected Moses's message.

parts: Give this common English name denoting Tibetan and Egyptian texts about the afterlife.

In one poem, a US Poet Laureate with this surname likens "sunlight" to a leaf from an "Appalachian Book of the Dead". Another author with this surname wrote over 4,000 haiku and a novel featuring the lawyer Boris Max.
This poet's Book of the Dead describes the Gauley Tunnel mining disaster in West Virginia. Her best-known poem declares that "to be" part of the title ethnicity "is to be offered a gift".

answers: quantitative structure-activity relationships [or QSAR models; prompt on SAR models]
parts: Name these chemicals, whose bioavailability, potency, and toxicity determine which candidates will eventually advance to clinical trials.
These computational models in drug discovery use regression analysis to predict how effective a candidate drug's action will be based on its chemical and physical characteristics.
The ability of a candidate drug to enter the target tissue depends on this quantity, which is the equilibrium ratio of the concentration of a molecule within two immiscible solvents.
